title: Haverhill police chief retires amid no confidence vote, criticism after officer’s death
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Local News “I have accepted his resignation.
And while his departure ends a chapter, it is not the end of the story,” the mayor said.
File - A cruiser from the Haverhill Police Department.

title: Pro-Palestine protesters arrested after clash with police now facing felony charges, including inciting a riot
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Local News The charges of inciting a riot — a felony — are being brought under a state law that prohibits the "promotion of anarchy.
" Boston police officers detain a protestor during a pro-Palestinian protest.
Bryan Hecht/Berkeley Beacon ShareSend this article to your social connections.

title: When a person is arrested by ICE, families, advocates, and local officials sometimes have to piece together who was taken
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Local News “Sometimes family members immediately come to us, so we know who a detainee is right away.
Other times it takes more effort and help from a range of directions after someone is detained.
” A protest sign is seen in front of an ICE vehicle outside of the Boston ICE field office in Burlington, Massachusetts October 1, 2025.

title: Boston police officer hospitalized after being struck by vehicle in Mattapan
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Local News The officer was doing detail work in Mattapan when a vehicle ran over their foot, according to a police spokesperson.
By Darin Zullo October 9, 2025 | 6:01 PM Less than a minute to read ShareSend this article to your social connections.
A Boston police officer was injured Thursday after being struck by a vehicle in Mattapan, according to police.

title: ‘He’s on a plan’: Christian Gonzalez pops up on Patriots’ injury report after being limited at practice
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: New England Patriots "It's kind of a warm-up to the early portion of practice.
" Christian Gonzalez John Tlumacki/The Boston Globe FOXBOROUGH — After a pair of healthy weeks, Christian Gonzalez popped back up on the Patriots’ injury report on Thursday.
He was listed as a limited participant at practice due to a hamstring injury.

title: Photos of Boston mobsters at Savin Hill restaurant upset residents
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Food News One of the photos at the Savin Hill restaurant is of a Whitey Bulger mugshot.
This 1953 Boston police booking photo shows James "Whitey" Bulger after an arrest.

(Boston Police via AP) A Dorchester restaurant that replaced the former Bulldog Tavern — once owned by a man tied to James “Whitey” Bulger’s Winter Hill Gang — is facing backlash after hanging photos of famous Boston mobsters on its walls following a renovation.

title: Fire in Everett apartment being investigated as suspicious, department says
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Local News Anyone with information about the fire can call the Arson Watch Reward Program at 1-800-682-9229.

title: What Louisiana native Will Campbell said about returning to the Superdome
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: New England Patriots "A lot of people that have supported me throughout this whole process, it will be their first time seeing me play in person, so it will be cool.

" Will Campbell AP Photo/Charles Krupa FOXBOROUGH — Will Campbell was fielding questions at his locker about his upcoming return to his home state of Louisiana when Drake Maye walked by and yelled “smile for ’em, Big Country.
”“Do they really call you Big Country?

title: Is the Drake Maye hype enough to keep Josh McDaniels with the Patriots for good?
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: New England Patriots "It would be surprising if move my kids out of Westwood, come hell or high water," McDaniels said.
"I don't know if I'll be here or not, but it is what it is.

" Josh McDaniels and Drake Maye AP Photo/Charles Krupa FOXBOROUGH — Josh McDaniels blinked his eyes, leaned his head back, and mimed a miniature explosion with his hands as if his mind was blown by the question.

title: Mass. Senate considers bill to place Narcan at all MBTA stations
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Local News The bill seeks to expand a pilot program that installed naloxone at five Red Line stations.
Steve Jesi points to a Narcan distribution box that was installed inside Flint Public Library in Middleton that was put in at his urging.

(Jessica Rinaldi/Globe Staff) By Annie Jonas October 9, 2025 | 3:51 PM 2 minutes to read The Massachusetts Senate is considering a proposal to add naloxone – a life-saving medication that can reverse overdoses – at all MBTA stations, in an effort to address the state’s opioid crisis.
